Award.AwardTitle: Nonlinear Dynamics in Structured Biological and Epidemiological Models
Award.AbstractNarration:
Human health and the integrity of ecosystems face increasing challenges from biological invasions. The movement of various nonindigenous vectors (e.g., mosquitoes) has resulted in epidemics and the spread of human diseases such as dengue, malaria, and West Nile virus. West Nile virus is a not only a threat to human health, but also to native ecosystems, since vulnerable native species can be driven into extinction by this introduced pathogen, creating detrimental effects that can cascade through an ecosystem. Ecosystems may also be disrupted directly by certain animal invaders. An example is the pike killifish, a non-native fish in the Everglades that can migrate into freshwater marshes and prey on the small forage fishes that would otherwise support the wading bird community. The emergence of antimicrobial-resistant bacteria is another type of biological invasion and infections caused by antimicrobial-resistant bacteria are a serious public health threat. Thus, it is essential to have simulation tools to forecast the spatial spread and effects of such invasions. Each of these biological and epidemiological problems can be studied by using structured population models to determine the birth, growth and death rates of individuals and their interactions with the environment and with each other. The goal of this project is to construct such forecasting tools and to investigate how the essential structuring variables (e.g., age, size, maturity level, location, latency) affect the properties of these invasive systems the associated epidemiological outcomes.

The goals of this project are: (i) Study the transmission dynamics of West Nile virus in the U.S. and explore useful and effective prevention measures. Based on the features and characteristics on the transmission of West Nile virus, both ordinary differential equation models and structured models will be applied. (ii) Develop spatially-structured models to investigate the role of environmental contamination on the clinical epidemiology of antibiotic-resistant bacteria in hospitals focusing on the interactions between health-care workers, patients and the environment. (iii) Investigate the invasion by small piscivorous fish in freshwater marsh landscapes in the southern Florida Everglades by constructing and analyzing advection-reaction-diffusion models. Since various structured models can be written as abstract semilinear equations, the nonlinear dynamics of semilinear equations with non-dense domain will be studied and the theoretical results will be applied to specific biological and epidemiological problems.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The major goal of this project was to construct forecasting tools and to investigate how the essential structuring variables (e.g., age, size, maturity level, location, latency) affect the properties of invasive systems and the associated biological and epidemiological outcomes. In the funded research, the PI has (i) studied the nonlinear dynamics of semilinear equations with non-dense domain and applied to structured models in epidemiology and population dynamics; (ii) studied spatio-temporal dynamics and traveling wave solutions of reaction-diffusion equations and applied to biological and epidemiological problems; (iii) investigated the transmission dynamics of some emerging and re-emerging infectious diseases and antibiotic resistant bacteria in hospitals and communities. Since various structured models can be written as abstract semilinear equations, the nonlinear dynamics of semilinear equations with non-dense domain will be studied and the theoretical results will be applied to specific biological and epidemiological problems. The main findings are summarized as follows.

(a) Semilinear Equations with Non-dense Domain. In the last ten years the PI and his collaborators have been systematically developing theories for abstract semilinear equations with non-dense domain, including basic theory, center manifold theory, Hopf bifurcation theorem, normal form theory, and applying to some structured biological models. Supported by the prior grant, in the last four years we continued to study the nonlinear dynamics of of abstract semilinear equations with non-dense domain. In Chu et al. (2016) we developed a normal form theory for an age-structured model. In Liu et al. (2016)we considered an age-structured model of uni-directional consumer-resource mutualisms, discussed the stability of the positive equilibrium, and showed that under some conditions non-trivial periodic solutions appear through Hopf bifurcation. In Yang et al. (2015), global stability of an age-structured virus dynamics model with Beddington-DeAngelis infection function was studied.

(b) Spatio-temporal Dynamics and Traveling Waves in Reaction-diffusion Systems. The PI and his collaborators have been investigating the spatio-temporal dynamics of reaction-diffusion equations and have established some fundamental results on the existence of traveling waves. We have continued doing research on this topic in the last four years. Lin & Ruan (2016) studied traveling wave solutions for delayed reaction-diffusion systems with applications to diffusive Lotka-Volterra competition models with and without delay. Wu & Ruan(2015) investigated entire solutions for a general nonlocal dispersal monostable equation with spatio-temporal delay. Zhao & Ruan (2015) obtained the precise decay rates of traveling waves for a class of nonlocal evolution equations arising in the theory of phase transitions and mathematical biology. Xu et al. (2018) studied fast propagation in reaction-diffusion systems. In Wang et al. (2016), we studied the existence, uniqueness and stability of 3-D traveling fronts of pyramidal shape for monotone bistable systems of reaction-diffusion equations in R^3 and applied to Lotka-Volterra competition-diffusion systems with or without spatio-temporal delays, and reaction-diffusion systems of multiple obligate mutualists. In Shi & Ruan (2015), the spatial, temporal and spatiotemporal dynamics of a reaction-diffusion predator-prey system with mutual interference described by Crowley-Martin-type functional response, under homogeneous Neumann boundary conditions, are studied. The spatiotemporal dynamics of a diffusive Leslie-Gower predator-prey system with ratio-dependent Holling type III functional response were considered in Shi et al. (2015). Zhang et al. (2017) studied a diffusive predator-prey model with Beddington-DeAnglelis functional response describing the interactions of small fishes and their resource base (small invertebrates) in the fluctuating freshwater marsh landscapes of the Florida Everglades.

(c) Modeling Antibiotic-resistant Bacterial Infection in Hospitals and Communities. The PI and his collaborators have been working on this topic for more than ten years. Supported by the prior grant, Wang & Ruan  (2017) proposed a deterministic model as well as a stochastic model to describe the transmission characteristics of Methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA) in hospital setting. In Huang et al. (2018), we study the effect of seasonal drug administration on the spread of antibiotic-resistant bacteria in hospitals.

(d) Modeling Some Specific Infectious Diseases. The PI has followed the outbreaks of emerging and re-emerging infectious diseases worldwide closely, has tried to study the transmission of some of these infectious diseases (H7N9 avian influenza, HBV, rabies, Rift Valley fever, Schistosomiasis, West Nile virus, Zika), and has obtained some timely results. For example, in Gao et al. (2017), we introduced a mathematical model to investigate the impact of mosquito-borne and sexual transmission on the spread and control of ZIKV and calibrate the model to ZIKV epidemic data from Brazil, Colombia, and El Salvador. Based on this study, the PI was interviewed by the media such as Canadian Television Network (CTV) and the National Public Radio (WLRN, WGCU).

(e) Magal and Ruan (2018) finished a monograph "Theory and Applications of Abstract Semilinear Cauchy Problems" to be published by Springer, pp 533.

(f) The PI has suppervised four Ph.D. students in the last four years.

(g) The PI presented lectures on his reserach at various national and international conferences and workshops and at various universities.


Last Modified: 09/01/2018
Modified by: Shigui Ruan
